div.ab: The ladies played at a game called the Saints. The company took different names as St Antoão St Ursula &c. Each had a veil one of the ladies went round and lifting up the veil asked who would buy such a saint describing him or her & her qualities in a ludicrous way. whoever laughed paid forfeit and stood up to sell the saints.

The impudent attempt frequently printed to make Latin & Portuguese the same Noted by many travellers, including Robert Southey, Letters Written during a Journey in Spain, and a Short Residence in Portugal, 3rd edn, 2 vols (London, 1808), vol. 2, p. 62. WG's hand and the passage's positioning suggests that this was a later addition rather than an observation during his own travels. WG has two more lines than Southey (lines that appear in other versions), though, and WG uses different punctuation, so Southey was not his source.

lg.l: Canto tuas palmas famosos canto triumphos
Subjectas sacra nympha feros animosa tirannos
Tu phoenix vivendo ardes ardendo triumphos
Das rosa bella rosas fortes das sancta columnas
Æternas vivas annos o regia planta
Devoto cantando hymnos, vos invoco sanctas
Tam puras nymphas amo adoro canto celebro
Per vos felices annos o candida turba.
Per vos innumeros de Christo spero favores.
